Benter runs a hotel, a business she has done for the last six years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 30,000. She has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya of Kshs. 20,000, which she will use to add a stock of cooking ingredients, vegetables, meat and cereals for cooking in her hotel.

With the anticipated profits, Benter will be able to pay school fees for her children. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to have a stable source of income through which her family's needs can be catered for.

loans.use: to add a stock of cooking ingredients, vegetables, meat and cereals

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Her name is Corazon, 62; she is a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Gonzalo, a carpenter, and is a mother to their eight children. She and her husband work hard to meet their everyday needs and to support her children's schooling. 

Corazon operates a tricycle. She sells rice and charcoal as well. Her  husband drives the tricycle that carries up to four passengers. In the Philippines, especially in the provinces like Palawan, a tricycle is a common means of transportation. Jeepneys and buses are limited. Very few people own a vehicle. The town people usually ride a tricycle from their homes to market, church, to their friend’s homes, and to other destinations within their community. They even transport from one town to the other. She earns a minimum of Php 1,500 a day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 25,000 loan, which she will use for repairs and maintenance of her tricycle, and to buy rice and charcoal to sell. She is positive that this will boost her income, as tricycle transportation, and rice and charcoal are necessities.

Corazon plans to buy another tricycle unit to improve her income. She prays that her children will lead a godly and better life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and were she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for her tricycle maintenance, and also to pay for sacks of rice and charcoal

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena is a married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Lucena is 57 years old, and has one child who is in school.

Lucena has a sewing business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy garments to use in her business.

Lucena has been in this business for three years.  In the future, she would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy garments to use in her business

loans.name: Rafik

texts.en:
Rafik lives in Aragats village with his mother. He studies at University, and specializes in construction. The only worker in the family is Rafik's mother, who is employed in the private sector. Her salary is hardly enough for covering their daily needs. 

Rafik has applied for this loan so he can pay for his university tuition, so he can pay for his education and continue his studies.

loans.use: to pay for university tuition

loans.name: Manal

texts.en: Because Manal is a conservative lady, she asked her husband to take her place in the picture. Manal was born in 1978. She is married and lives in Karak, Jordan. Manal has been running her own business selling clothes and shoes for one year. She started this business by opening a clothing store, and then opened a shoe store nearby that her husband is currently running. Her business has been profitable and has grown significantly. She is now seeking to expand it more by buying a new collection of shoes to sell, and she is applying for this loan so she can buy a good quantity of stock.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar is 29 years old and has one child. She is a very hard  working entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her business.

Maricar has been in this business for three years.  In the future, she would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar is a 36-year-old married man living in Irbid, Jordan with his six family members. He has been the only provider for the family. 

He is seeking to expand his car repair shop that he is currently running to be able to provide his children with what they need. 

Now his shop is running out of some products that he needs, and he has applied for this loan to be able to purchase new tools and products for the shop, such as tires and car oil.

loans.use: to get more tires, car oil, and new tools

loans.name: Myra

texts.en: Myra is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Myra is 36 years old and has five children, whom are in school. Myra has a funeral business in the Philippines. Myra has requested a PHP 8000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more coffins and other materials for her funeral business. Myra has been in this business for 12 years now.  In the future, Myra would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more materials for her funeral business

loans.name: Fred

texts.en: Fred is a married father of three. He is an agriculturalist who also makes and sells bricks. He used his previous loan to produce more bricks, which increased his income. Fred now needs another loan to buy fire wood so that he can bake more bricks. He is hard working and thanks Kiva lenders for their generosity.

loans.use: to buy firewood for making bricks

loans.name: Antedia

texts.en: Antedia is 49 years old and married. She works very hard to provide for their needs. Antedia is in the agricultural business in the Philippines. Antedia has requested a PHP 6000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. Antedia has been in this business for 5 years now, and has borrowed 2 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Antedia would like to save enough to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma is a married woman with ten children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Elma is 45 years old and has eight children who are in school. Elma has a food vending business in the Philippines. Elma has requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business. Elma has been in this business for 24 years now. In the future, Elma would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Abel

texts.en: Abel is a new client to the institution. He is single however he has one child. He resides in the Kayembe cell of the Rukungiri municipality. He operates a mobile money business at a trading centre, which he has done for one year now. He also works with MTN as a sales person. Abel has applied for a loan of 3,000,000 UGX to boost his business so as to meet the needs of his customers and increase his earnings. Abel hopes to expand his business using this loan from Ugafode. He thanks Ugafode for its financial assistance, which has improved many peoples’ lives in his area.

loans.use: to increase mobile money float

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine is a student in her third year of studying in Yerevan State University of Armenia. 

This is her second loan from Kiva.

With responsible payments of her first loan behind her, Karine now asks lenders to support her with university tuition for her third year course of studies.
 
Karine will be very grateful to Kiva lenders if they support her one more time with her higher education.

loans.use: to pay for university tuition for the third year course.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: Rosa is 37 years old and has four children. Rosa is a married woman and has four children who are in school. Rosa is in the agricultural business in the Philippines, where she raises pigs. She has requested a PHP 5000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. Rosa has been doing this business for 2 years now, and has borrowed 1 time in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Rosa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Manal

texts.en:
Manal is a 38-year-old married woman. Her husband works at a governmental entity. 

Manal has been making detergents at her house and selling them for two years, and her husband has been helping her in selling her products using his car to deliver them to people of his neighborhood. 

She is seeking to open a detergents store near her house in the future to gain better profit. She currently needs to bring in more raw materials and detergents to serve the customers faster and expand her business. For that she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials and detergents to sell.

loans.name: Together Group

texts.en: These are the members of the group called Together. They are small-scale business people based in Teshie-Accra, Ghana. This is the fourth loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from ID Ghana. With this loan, they will be able to expand their individual businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their families' standards of living. The featured borrower of this group is Robert, aged 37. He is single and has no dependent children. He sells groceries and soft drinks. He was born in Teshie, a town in coastal Ghana. He attended elementary school and lives in his family's house. Robert has been selling groceries and soft drinks for the past ten years. With this loan, he will buy more groceries and soft drinks for increasing his current inventory for sale. This is his fourth loan with ID Ghana. Their group will need a total amount of 4,400 GHS to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to buy more groceries and soft drinks for increasing his current inventory for sale.

loans.name: Blanca Isabel

texts.es: Blanca vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella tiene un taller de confección de ropa ubicado en su lugar de residencia desde hace 13 años, tiene muchos clientes por la calidad de su trabajo y los buenos precios, ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de más telas, hilos, agujas, botones y todo lo necesario para la costura y así tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Blanca lives in her own house with her husband.   For the past 13 years, she has  had a sewing workshop for clothing, whch is located in her residence.

  Because of the quality of her work and her good prices, Blanca has many customers.  She is asking for a loan to buy more fabric, thread, needles, buttons and everything needed for sewing clothes,  so that she can earn a better income.

loans.use: to buy more fabric, thread, needles, buttons and everything needed to sew clothing

loans.name: Tukur

texts.en:
Tukur is a maize farmer from Tunkuna village. 

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Tukur would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Tukur can now store his maize at harvest and sell it for up to 40% higher than the prices at harvest time. This allows Tukur to generate earnings of up to $1000/hectare, more than four times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 

When asked, Tukur said: “I would now be able use this extra income to expand my farmland, and eventually, I hope to become the most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: to meet urgent expenses, child school fees and food and farm loan repayments by eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Joseph is 37 years of age and one of the most hardworking men in his village of Kapsumai, in the area of Kapsowar in Kenya. He has a wife and four children and wanted to lay a good foundation for his family and grandchildren to come. That is why he started farming and has been practicing mixed farming for the past six years. 

His primary sources of income have been eggs, crops, and some personal business that he does so as to accumulate more wealth. Joseph is very passionate about dairy farming and, as he always says, “dairy farming is close to my heart.” He has nicknamed his dairy cow “Chelenge.” (Blemish). 

Dairy farming in Kenya has seen an upsurge in growth, and milk prices in the recent past have skyrocketed. This has translated to increased earnings for farmers. Joseph, being a very hardworking and visionary farmer, will want to take advantage of the ready market; that is why he is kindly seeking a loan from Kiva lenders via Juhudi Kilimo to buy a good-quality breed of dairy cow. 

Joseph has already decided what type of dairy breed he requires and, because of his immense knowledge on preparing hay, his cows will have plenty of food and will produce more milk. Joseph projects that the cow he acquires through the loan will be producing more than 10 liters a day. Because there is a ready market for milk, he does not worry too much about competition and marketing the milk will not be a challenge. He will be selling it directly to the market as well as to big dairy-processing firms, which will result in increased earnings. Additionally, Joseph has planned that instead of selling the milk in its raw form, he will be packaging the milk, and this will also improve his income. 

Profits from selling milk will enable Joseph to be very successful. He also plans that through accumulated profits, he will be able to construct a bio gas digester to produce energy that he will use in cooking and other domestic chores.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 47 years old and married. She has three children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Marilou runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, shampoo, milk, beverages, etc.

Marilou has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as rice, sugar, soap, and other groceries. 

In the future, Marilou would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, shampoo, milk, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cows

loans.name: Rasha

texts.en:
Rasha was born in 1982. She is a married woman who has been supporting her husband financially to help him improve their living conditions. 

She started selling clothes to people who live in her area one year ago, and she wants to open her own clothes store in the future to raise her income. 

Now she is planning to expand her business by getting a new collection of babies' and women's clothes for the upcoming winter season, but because she doesn’t have enough money to do so, she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase a new collection of babies' and women's winter clothes.

loans.name: Ashok

texts.en:
Ashok is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children in a small, old house. Three of his children go to school, while his eldest son works in a banana company. 

Ashok is working to build a new house, so that his children have a better and larger place to study. Ashok wants to finish building his house and requested a loan of SRD 10,000. Ashok is a client of Seva MFI and always repays his loans on time.

loans.use: to finish building his house.

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Rosa de 39 años de edad y vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus tres hijos, ella posee desde hace 5 años una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia, tiene muchos clientes por los buenos precios y la amabilidad que tiene a la hora de vender, ella está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar más sopas, huevos, granos básicos, refrescos, golosinas, pan dulce, etc. y así poder tener mejores ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Rosa, 39, lives in her own home with her husband and their three children. For 5 years, she has owned a small shop in her home. She has many customers due to her good prices and her friendly demeanor in sales. She is requesting this loan to buy more soup, eggs, basic grains, drinks, sweets, sweet bread, and other items so she can earn more income and have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more soup, eggs, basic grains, drinks, sweets, sweet bread, and other items.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is 49 and a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. She is married to Francisco, a carpenter, and has four children. She works hard to augment their income to meet their daily personal and household needs and the school needs of her children.

Aurora has a backyard piggery farm and has been a hog raiser for two years already. Investing in the piggery is a good and profitable business as female pigs conceive twice in a year and can produce as much as 12 piglets each time. Her piglets are sold to cook as "lechon" (roasted pig) and also the fresh meat sold at the town market. She earns at least 11,000 PHP a month from her piggery.  

To help her continue operation of her business she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan which she will use to buy hogs, more feed and clean grain for her pigs. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.
 
Aurora aims to grow her business to have a better life.  She wants to give her children the best education until college for a bright future.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for feeds and additional hogs needed in her business.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 45 and a resident of Coron, Palawan in the Philippines. She is married to Gilbert, a branch manager of a security office and they have two kids.  Jenny is a hardworking woman and has two businesses to augment their income, to provide for their daily needs and school needs of her children. 

Jenny has a tailoring business. Aside from her tailoring, she also has a general store. She regularly makes dresses such as school uniforms and also during special occasions like Graduation day, Mother's Day and Christmas season. She is known to be a good sewer in their area. She earns a minimum of Php15000 a month from her two businesses. 

To help her expand her tailoring business, she is requesting for an 50000 Php loan to buy more fabrics, thread and other items as well as a new sewing machine to meet the higher demand for dresses this coming Christmas season. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. Her earnings will be a big help to address their daily needs and to send her children to school.

Jenmy hopes that her business will grow. She dreams to give her family a better future and be able to send her child to the best school until college. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

 *All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for fabrics and buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Her name is Delia, 61, resident of Silang Cavite, Philippines. Married to Arturo, a truck driver, she has children. Together with her husband, she manages their own household. She works hard to augment their income to meet their daily household expenses and school needs of her children.

Delia has a small apartment for rent and she also makes and sells native delicacies such as rice cakes. These are commonly eaten for snacks and also for desserts. She sells per order and on demand on special occasions and holidays. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 3,000 a month in sales and PHP 12,000 rental income per month.

To help her continue with her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan which she will use for the repair of her apartment. Part of the loan  will be used to buy raw ingredients such as sticky rice, flour, sugar, and coconut milk that she needs to cook rice cakes for sale. She is positive of a good turnout for her business. She thanks God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Delia aims to grow her business so she can send her children to school. She prays to stay strong and healthy for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for repair and maintenance of her rental apartment and also to buy ingredients for her native delicacies.

loans.name: Oscar Alejandro

texts.es:
Oscar, vive en casa de sus padres de 47 y 45 años de edad, ahí mismo viven sus hermanas de 15 y 20 años de edad, el ayuda con los gastos familiares; su negocio consiste en venta de CD´S y DVD´S, también ofrece artículos plásticos para uso domésticos, atiende a sus clientes todos los días, su negocio está ubicado en el mercado de la cuidad, ya cuenta con 5 años de experiencia.
Comprará CD´S, DVD´S, basureros, canastas, etc., su inventario estará surtido, espera atraer nuevos clientes, tener mejores ganancias y cancelar su deuda para continuar haciendo uso de créditos que le ayuden a mejorar su actividad económica.
Para Oscar su sueño es mantener su negocio en el mercado para seguir cubriendo sus gastos personales y apoyar económicamente a sus padres.
texts.en:
Oscar lives in his parents’ house; they are 47 and 45 years old.  His 15 and 20 year old sisters live there, too.  He helps with the family expenses.  

His business is selling CD’s and DVD’s.  He also sells plastic goods for domestic use.  He tends to his customers every day.  His business is located at the city market.  He now has five years of experience.

He will buy CD’s, DVD’s, garbage cans, and baskets, etc.  His inventory will be stocked.  He hopes to attract new customers, to have better earnings, and to repay his debt in order to continue making use of the loans that will help him improve his business activity.

Oscar’s dream is to maintain his business in the market in order to continue covering his personal expenses and to financially support his parents.

loans.use: to buy CD’s, DVD’s, garbage cans, and baskets, etc. to stock his inventory.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria, 59, is a married woman with five children and one of her children is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Victoria has a mat weaving business in the Philippines. Victoria has been in this business for 10 years.

Victoria requested a PHP 20,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials for her mat weaving business. 

In the future, Victoria would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for her mat weaving business.

loans.name: Faluk

texts.en:
Faluk is a 40-year-old married man with six children all attending different schools. He is a retail shop operator in a trading centre. He works seven days a week and 12 hours a day.

He also deals in a produce business and a farming business as additional sources of income. He was motivated by the desire to earn a living. He usually sells his goods to fellow traders from surrounding areas.

He hopes to use the loan to buy fertilizers for his plantations. 

His hopes and dreams are to be the leading producer of agricultural products and to enlarge his business. He faces a challenge of limited capital and too much poverty among people, hence low markets for the products, which affects his operations.

He is described as an honest and shrewd man in business and appreciates the services of lenders.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and herbicides for his crops.

loans.name: Binyomo 3 Group

texts.en:
Binyomo 3 is a group of two ladies. They both live in Accra-Teshie, Ghana. They are asking for a loan of GHS 2,600 from ID-Ghana to sell fish and vegetable foodstuff. 

Victoria is a 38-year-old married woman with four children. She has been selling food stuffs and vegetables for four years. She supports her husband in taking care of the children by selling food stuffs and vegetables at her residence. She wants to improve her business, and most of what she earns goes to family expenses. Therefore, she is applying for a loan of GHS 1,000 from ID-Ghana in order to buy more food stuffs and vegetables to sell to customers.

She will save part of her profit and also invest back part after she finishes repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more food stuffs and vegetables to sell to customers.

loans.name: Matiyu

texts.en: Matiyu is a maize farmer from Kyasge village. As a member of Babban Gona, Matiyu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. As a result of his previous loan for inputs, Matiyu expects to reap up to 30 bags/hectare of maize, which is double the national average of 14 bags/hectare. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Matiyu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Matiyu can now store his maize at harvest and sell it for up to 40% higher than the prices at harvest time. This allows Matiyu to generate earnings of up to $1000/hectare, more than four times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. When asked, Matiyu said: “I would now be able use this extra income to expand my farmland, and eventually, I hope to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.”

loans.use: to access a loan to meet urgent expenses such as child school fees, food and  farm loan repayment

loans.name: Griselda

texts.en:
Griselda is 59 years old. She is a widow, and all her children are independent. She describes herself as a happy and calm person who likes to spend time with her family. She says that her kids think that she gets too worried and nervous. 

Griselda says that she is very responsible; she had to be after her husband died. She has a laundry that she opened some years ago, and she says that due to the good location, she has many clients and a stable income. Her biggest accomplishment is sending her kids to school and buying a taxi, which helps her to get additional income. She is asking for a loan to fix some machines in her laundry shop.

loans.use: To repair a laundry machine and a dryer.

loans.name: Zinalikuti Group

texts.en:
Melifa is 42 years old and married to Alfred, who is 50 years old. She owns a market stall selling beans, mixed vegetables, and groundnuts and is requesting this loan to buy these items in bulk to satisfy her customer needs. She has four children who go to school and she also looks after school-going orphans. Melifa started her business to be able to feed her family and pay school fees for her children.

Since she started borrowing funds, she has seen herself making more profits. She hopes to send her children to private schools and satisfy her family's basic needs. She also wants to have stock of groundnuts and beans in bulk. Being a woman, she is self-reliant and she has managed to buy a pushing bicycle for her family.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, beans and groundnuts.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha (pictured with her husband) is 25 years old, and has two daughters ages 8 and 6.  Together with her husband, she started a recycling business. They buy and sell used things such as mattresses, laundry machines, refrigerators and scrap metal and then sell them. She is asking for a loan to fix the truck that she uses to transport all the things that she buys and sells. She says that she is creditworthy because in the past she has taken loans and always repaid them on time.

loans.use: To repair the truck she uses to transport used things.

loans.name: Analissa

texts.en:
Analissa is grateful that she was granted a 50,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in her general store. Through her earnings she is able to send her child to school and meet their daily living expenses. 

She would now like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan, which she will use as part of her working capital to buy more quantities of grocery items such as sacks of rice, coffee, soda, rice noodles and other groceries. She knows that more items in her store will yield more sales and thus increase her earnings. 

Aside from her general store, she also operates a tricycle unit, which her husband drives for added income. Her income from her business is a stable source to meet her family's basic needs and educate her child. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. 

Analissa dreams of having a bigger general store and aims to give her child the best education until college. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God, which she studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Xejuyu Group

texts.en:
San Pedro La Laguna is one of twelve towns that dot the shore of magnificent Lake Atitlan in the highlands of Guaemala. It is located at the base of the volcano of the same name. San Pedro is among the most visited towns on the Lake and many come here to study Spanish or simply to socialize with other travelers. The population, called “Pedranos” are mainly Mayan Tzutujil and hold fast to their centuries old traditions and culture. 

The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Xejuyu” meaning “Under the Grand Mountain” was formed by seven women of the town who are motivated to improve their own lives and those of their families. 

Concepción is a member of the Trust Bank with nine children, some of whom are adults. Two of her younger children are about to graduate at the end of the year and she is quite pleased about this. This 55-year-old motivated woman has a coffee business as well as a textile business. She began her coffee business selling ground coffee, several years ago in order to pay for the basic expenses of her large family.  Concepción is also a talented seamstress and sews the beautiful blouses of San Pedro. She is requesting her second loan from Friendship Bridge that she will use to purchase coffee sacks for her successful coffee business, as well as a variety of supplies including thread and fabric for her textile business. At this time of the year, her textile business is expanding and she wants to be sure to have plenty of supplies on hand.

Concepción and her friends in the Trust Bank are learning to find their voice and gather important life skills through the educational component of their monthly meetings. They learn about topics that affect their daily lives from a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer. Taught in their own indigenous language using drawings, games and role playing, the women learn about their rights as women. They learn to use their loans wisely with new information about effective business management practices including budgeting, marketing, customer service and accounting. The ladies also gather information about health, hygiene, nutrition and the use of medicinal plants. Friendship Bridge calls the effective combination of loans and education “Microcredit Plus”.

loans.use: to purchase coffee sacks for her successful coffee business, as well as a variety of supplies including thread and fabric for her textile business

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is 59 years old. She is married and all of her sons are grownup and independent. She only lives with her husband. Margarita has been selling hats and clothing for the last 25 years. She started at a small local market and has been growing her business slowly but constantly. She works in different Mexico City flea markets.

Her biggest accomplishments have been starting and growing her business. She is asking for a loan to buy products and prepare for the end-of-year retail season, which is the best one of the year.

loans.use: to buy new models for end-of-year retail season.

loans.name: Rubie

texts.en:
Rubie, 25, is a married woman with two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Rubie has a mat weaving business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for one year. 

Rubie requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials for her mat weaving business. 

In the future, Rubie would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for her mat weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a cooler, shelve, display cases, and stock of basic needs products to start her store.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen is 54 years old, and has been married for the last 36 years. She has two married children. She likes to exercise, meet people, travel and dance.  She sells frozen drinks and snacks, both retail and wholesale. Carmen is asking for a loan to buy merchandise, in particular some new frozen products. She describes herself as hard working and credit worthy. Her biggest accomplishment is starting her business 9 years ago, and making it grow. Her goal is to buy a car.

loans.use: to buy a new line of frozen products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to renovate her house.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: This is 43-year-old Ibrahim. He is married and has four children aged 20, 16, 14 and 10 years. In 2003, Ibrahim established his powdered milk business. He began his business in order to enable him to settle his domestic problem. His business is located at the city centre and his main customers are women. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 1,500,000 SLL every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of 6,500,000 SLL. Ibrahim has already received and successfully repaid one loan and now requires a new loan in order to buy bags of powdered milk. He hopes that this loan will increase his capital base and his stock level. In the future, Ibrahim plans to rent his own store/shop, to build another house and to educate his children. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy packets of milk.

loans.name: Trabajadoras Hormiguitas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “TRABAJADORAS HORMIGUITAS” iniciará el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Verónica es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: tienda de abarrotes, taller de costura, tejido en mantas, taller de cerrajería.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Verónica es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de taller de costura; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió hace cinco años, cuando se caso, ya que su esposo realizaba este trabajo, con el pasar del tiempo ella aprendió el negocio y decidió emprender un negocio independiente. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de telas por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará por mayor en la ciudad de La Paz. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tiene un hijo.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las el área de salud, las capacitaciones y el crédito que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The Trabajadoras Hormiguitas comunal bank will start its fourth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Panamericana regional center.  It is comprised of eight members and led by a board of directors.  Verónica is the president.  The businesses of the members of the communal bank are varied and include a grocery store, seamstress shop, weaving blankets, and a locksmith shop.

The loan that they will take out will benefit small businesswomen where Verónica is a member.  She says that she joined Pro Mujer three years ago by invitation from a friend who is a client of the institution.  Her business is currently a sewing shop.  She says that she undertook this business five years ago when she got married because her husband did this work.  As time passed, she learned the business and decided to undertake an independent business.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase capital (to buy fabric wholesale).  She will get the fabric from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz.  After making the items, she will sells them wholesale in the city of La Paz.  This way of working allows her to generate resources to support her family.  She is married and has one child.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replied that she likes the health services, the trainings, and the loans that the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy fabric wholesale.

loans.name: Posiano

texts.en: Posiano lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged thirty-two and is a hardworking, married man with one child. He operates a retail shop mainly selling sugar, salt, and soap among other items. He hopes to expand and develop his business to wholesale trading. Posiano will use the loan to buy more salt and sugar to sell.

loans.use: to buy more salt and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes runs a hotel in Hoima, Uganda. She is aged forty-two years and charged with the responsibility of taking care of six children, who all attend school. She hopes to improve her business and pay school fees for her children as a loving mother. She will use the loan to buy more raw food for cooking in the hotel.

loans.use: to buy more raw food for cooking in the hotel.

loans.name: Glorious

texts.en: Glorious lives in Hoima, Uganda. She is aged thirty-two and charged with the responsibility of taking care of three children, two of whom attend school. She sells clothes and gets additional income from selling accessories and panels and also farming. She is a hardworking woman who hopes to develop her business. Glorious intends to use the loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Dan Lamber

texts.en: Dan Lamber lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is aged thirty-two and is married with four children, two of whom attend school. He operates a retail shop mainly selling sugar, rice, plastics, and domestic utensils. His dream is to expand his business and pay school fees for his children. He is requesting a loan to buy a refrigerator and a solar panel for using in his shop.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator and a solar panel for using in his shop.

loans.name: Martha Alicia

texts.en: Martha Aliciao is 20 years old and has a 3-years-old son. She is a single mother. She lives in a rented apartment which is located in the same street where she works. Martha works in a clothing manufacturing plant, where she is in charge of production. She is asking for a loan to buy a computer. She says that, with a laptop, she will be able to do some work from home and spend more time with her baby.

loans.use: to buy a computer to increase her productivity.

loans.name: Sarai

texts.en: Sarai is 25 years old. She has a son and lives in her grandparents' house. She describes herself as happy and independent. She rents a small place where she cooks and sells Mexican snacks. She is asking for a loan to refurbish the place and buy some tables and chairs. She hopes to get more clients and increase her sales. She started the business two years ago and says that her biggest accomplishment is becoming independent. Her hope is to keep growing her business.

loans.use: to refurbish her food snack business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 50 and a resident of Coron, Palawan in the Philippines. She is married to Romeo, a farmer and has three children, of which the eldest is in college and the other two are in high school. She manages her household while operating her business. She works hard to augment their income to support and meet their daily personal, household needs and to send her three children to school. 

Susan operates a small general store. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Aside from her store she also has a boarding house and a backyard piggery. She earns a minimum net income of Php 600 a day from her store business and Php3000 rental income a month. 

To help her continue operations of her general store business, Susan is requesting a Php 20000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as sacks of rice, charcoal, soda and other groceries. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. Her earnings is their source to meet their daily expense and to send her children to school. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Susan hopes to maintain and grow her business so her family can have a better life. She strives to hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Yorn, 47, lives in a small community of Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has two dependent children, who currently are working in one private garment factory. To make a living, she has been involved in agri-business since 1985. By owning farmland, she grows rice and sells her crops to the local dealers. Sometimes she sells directly to customers at the market. On average, she is able to make an income of USD 2.50 per day. Yorn is living in a very old house, which some of its parts need to be renovated. Because there is not enough money, she is now applying for a KIVA loan through HKL to pay for her house renovation. Through this loan, she hopes that she will get a better living standard after the house is renovated. She would like to thank to all the lenders for their financial support. She is awaiting your kindness.

loans.use: to pay for her house renovation

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Dy is a 21-year-old university student. He lives with his parents in Tbong Khmum province, Cambodia. Due to a lack of financial support, he would like to request a loan to pay for his university fees. This loan will help him graduate and provide him with a skill. Dy's dream is to become a high school teacher.

loans.use: to pay for his university fees

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Chanthy, 46, lives in a small community in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has one married child and two dependent children who are currently in school. To make a living, she has been involved in agribusiness since 2000. She owns a farm where she grows rice and sells the crops to the local dealers. Sometimes she also sells directly to customers at the market. Her husband, Nang, is a truck driver and he has a truck rental service. On average, this couple earns an income of USD 7.00 per day. 

Currently, the tires of the truck that her husband rents out are very old and they need to be replaced. Therefore, Chanthy would like to request a KIVA loan to buy new truck tires to replace the old ones. Last but not least, she would like to thank all the lenders for their financial support. She is awaiting your kindness.

loans.use: to buy new truck tires

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 52 and a resident of Coron, Palawan in the Philippines. He is married to Wilma, a businesswoman and has four children. His eldest is in college and the other three are not in school. He works hard to meet their daily household needs and for the schooling of his eldest.

Wilson is into a food business. He has operated an eatery stall for a nuner of years already. In the Philippines, a food stall is a common sight especially in populated areas. Working class usually buy their meals at food stalls sold at reasonable price for convenience and to save money than cook at home. The working class just eat their home-cooked meals at the end of the day with their family. He is a good cook that is why his food stall is popular in their area with neighbors and the local working community as his regular  customers. He earns a minimum of Php4000 net income a day from his food stall. Aside from his food business he also has a boat for rent to transport local and foreign tourists from one island to another, from which he earns a minimum of Php 2000 a day.

To help maintain his business, Wilson is requesting for a Php50000 loan to buy additional raw ingredients like pork, fish, chicken and seasonings that are needed for his cooking. Part of the loan will be used for the repair and maintenance of his tourist boat. He is positive that with this financial assistance, his sales and earnings will increase considerably. He is thanking God and you in advance for your great help.

Wilson dreams of a bigger eatery in the future. He also dreams for a better future and to maintain a harmonious and loving family. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God he studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for his food stall as well as for the repair and maintenance of his tourist boat.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha, 59, earns a living through her sari-sari (variety store) business. She lives with her husband and two children in the town of Leyte, Philippines. This business has given Editha the income that she needs to support the family. 

Editha would like to request a loan to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking oil, and condiments. A loan will allow her to augment her stocks, which she hopes will attract more buyers to her store.

Editha wants to make her business more profitable and sustainable.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of products to sell

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena is married, and she has 5 children. She is a businesswoman. She has a kiosk and she is very interested in her business. She started her business a few years ago using her own working capital of $1500. 

Helena is requesting a loan of  $1500 to improve her kiosk. She is taking a loan from Tuba Rai Metin to buy items needed to stock her kiosk such as milk, toothpaste, noodles, water, biscuits, cooking oils, coffee, and other things to sell including soft drinks and hard drinks. She is happy about taking a loan from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants used to improve her business and manage it well.

loans.use: To buy provisions to sell

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en: Marcelina lives in Viqueque, Timor-Leste. She is a businesswoman so she always finds ways to improve her business. She is requesting a loan of $600.00. Marcelina has a kiosk that she opened a year ago. She started her business with her own working capital of $500.00. So she will use this loan from Tuba Rai Metin to add to her working capital and buy more goods to keep in her store such as pens, shampoo, slippers, sugar, soft drinks and other things to sell. Marcelina says she will use this loan to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy pens, shampoo, slippers, sugar, soft drinks and other things to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 42 years old and married with three children, one of whom is in school. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jocelyn has been raising pigs for ten years and also earns additional income from farming rice and her ready-to-wear clothing retail business.

Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 35,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem, 48, lives in a small community of Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is a construction worker with an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband, Savy, 47, is a construction worker who can make USD 2.50 per day too. Sem has one dependent child who is in school and one married child who is a motorcycle mechanic.

Sem wants her son to run a motorcycle repair service yet she lacks capital to invest. Thus, she is applying for a KIVA loan via HKL to buy some motorcycle spare parts for her son to run a motorcycle repair service business. Last but not least, Sem would like to thank all the lenders for their financial support. She is awaiting your kindness.

loans.use: to buy some motorcycle spare parts for her son

loans.name: Susana Zoila

texts.es:
La socia Susana se sigue dedicando al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azucar, leche y galletas, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azucar y leche .

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Susana continues to work at her grocery store. She sells staple goods such as rice, sugar, milk and biscuits. Susana works from 8am until 7pm. She has had the business for five years and it is going very well. Susana's dream is to expand her grocery store. Susana is applying for a loan in order to buy rice, sugar and milk.

Susana is happy with this loan and promises to make her repayments.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and milk.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
A 46-year-old married woman, Nenita makes a living through her sari-sari, or variety store, selling various goods to the people in her area. She lives with her family in Leyte, Philippines. For several years now, this business has provided the income that Nenita needs.

Now Nenita has hopes of expanding her business but lacks the capital to do so. This is why she is requesting a loan to buy more stock to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, rice, condiments, bread, snack foods, soap and toiletries. With this loan, she will be able to improve her stock, thus attracting more buyers to her store. 

In the future, Nenita hopes to make her business more sustainable and productive.

loans.use: to buy more stock such as canned goods, noodles, rice, condiments, bread, snack foods, soap and toiletries

loans.name: Juvelyn

texts.en:
Juvelyn is a hard-working woman from the Philippines. She is married and has three children. For more than a year now, Juvelyn has managed a small sari-sari (variety) store. This business provides her with the income that she needs in order to pay for the family's expenses, especially her children's education. 

Juvelyn is asking for a loan to buy more stocks of merchandise to sell such as canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking oil, and condiments. With this loan, she hopes to be able improve the inventories in her store, thus attracting more buyers. In the future, Juvelyn hopes to make her business a successful one.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of merchandise to sell

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 54 years old and married with five children.

Editha earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Editha has been raising pigs for 30 years and also earns additional income from farming rice and running a general store.

Editha is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Editha is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, which is to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 51 years old and married with six children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Lolita has an animal sales business in the Philippines. Lolita has been in this business for four years.

Lolita requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more pigs to offer for sale.

In the future, Lolita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more pigs to offer for sale.

loans.name: Recardina

texts.en: Recardina lives in Viqueque, Timor-Leste. She is married and has 4 children. She has been involved in business activities since 2007 when she started with her own working capital of $700.00. She is requesting a loan of $1000.00, because she has a kiosk and she is very interested to expand her business. She is taking a loan from Tuba Rai Mentin which she wants to use to buy more goods such as aqua, detergent, slippers, cigarettes, candies, shampoo, biscuits, instant noodles, candles, soft drinks, hard drinks and other things to sell. She needs to take a loan from Tuba Rai Metin, because she wants to improve the management of her business and to increase her income in the future.

loans.use: to buy aqua, detergent, slippers, cigarettes, candies, shampoo, biscuits, instant noodles, candles, soft drinks, hard drinks and other things to sell.

loans.name: Azucena

texts.en: Azucena is 55 years old and married with five children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Azucena is borrowing PHP 29000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. Azucena has been raising pigs for ten years and also earns additional income from farming rice. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, which is to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Elda

texts.en:
Elda is requesting a loan of $1500 to improve her business. She sells gasoline because she earns a good income. She lives near the main road, so every day many people come to buy her gasoline and she is still happy doing her business. Elda is taking this loan because she wants to purchase more gasoline. 

Elda has been involved in business activities since 2006, when she started with her own working capital of $500. When Tuba Rai Metin offered her this loan, she said the funds will help her to improve her management so that she can run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: To buy gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Socheat is 34 years old, a widowed vegetable seller with a 12-year-old child. She lives in Kampong Chhnang province of Cambodia. Her child attends school. She has been in the vegetable business since 2005, earning $5 daily. 

To improve her family’s finances, Socheat would like a loan to buy a cow for breeding calves to resell. This loan will help her earn more income. In the future, she is going to buy more cows to breed and support her child to reach high education.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Taman Sari Group

texts.en:
The Taman Sari group share their story. During the past 6 months, they have succeeded to raise pigs. The pigs have grown healthy and fat and they sold them at a satisfactory profit. We are happy to tell all the lenders that the members of Taman Sari have been successful to manage their pig business and they want to continue this business. They are very grateful and wish to give thanks to all lenders, Kiva and MUK for supporting their business with loans and training. MUK has decided to give them an increased loan size.

There’s a change in composition of the board. They have chosen a new head, Gusti Ayu, to replace Ni Luh as the last head. Gusti Ayu successfully sold her pigs for fattening and her sow has given her 8 healthy piglets. She also sold them all. Gusti Ayu and all her family feel the benefit of this business. She can fullfill her family's needs. Gusti Ayu has decided to take a new loan to increase her business and she hopes to have enough capital to run the business by herself.

Gusti Ayu is a housewife and her husband works as a farmer. The pigs business has proven to support her family income. Her husband helps her to maintain the pigs. This loan will be used to purchase feeds and renovate the pigs cage. She expect the sow will give birth again soon. She plans to become a piglets seller. She dreams to have a nice kitchen and she hope she can make this come true by running this business.

2 of their group members couldn't attend the meeting because of illness and attending a religious ceremony in the temple.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and renovate the cage

loans.name: Mertha Sedana Group

texts.en:
The members of the Mertha Sedana group are located in middle part of Bali, near the village of Baturiti. This group wants to borrow a 30,000,000 IDR loan and they can repay it on time. The borrowers are represented by the head of the group, Ni Ketut.

Ni Ketut told us that her pig-raising business is developing well. Before her previous loan, she had only 1 pig. With the help of the loan, she now has 6 piglets and 1 sow. The sow gave birth to 9 healthy piglets, which she sold after 5 months to pay off the loan. She also set aside some savings and fulfilled her family's daily needs. 

All the members of Mertha Sedana feel the benefits of raising pigs. They can support their husbands' income. The group expects another training from MUK to improve their knowledge of pig breeding.

The Mertha Sedana group has requested its new loan from MUK. With 10 members, the total loan amount is 30,000,000 IDR. (Two members couldn't attend the meeting because of a religious ceremony at the temple and another member had to attend her children's wedding.) The loan will be used to buy piglets and repair cages. Ni Ketut, as the head of the group, is using her portion of the loan to repair her cages and also to buy feed. She still has piglets in her cage. Superior pig specimens are currently very expensive, ranging from 400,000 - 500,000 IDR. These pigs will be maintained for 5 months for fattening.  During the loan period, Ni Ketut expects the pigs will be able to develop properly, without being attacked by disease. With this effort, she has a dream of fixing her house.

loans.use: to repair cages and buy feed

loans.name: Jennyfer

texts.en:
Jennyfer is 29 years old and married. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jennyfer has been raising pigs for five years and also earns additional income from a general store.

Jennyfer is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 17,000 PHP through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Rhoda successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. NWTF is presenting Rhoda's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Melda

texts.en:
Melda is a hard-working entrepreneur who has an animal sales business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF in order to buy more livestock to offer for sale.

Melda successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. NWTF is relisting Melda's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more livestock.

loans.name: Ricardo Antonio

texts.es: Ricardo de 37 años de edad se dedica desde hace 5 años a la agricultura (siembra maíz y frijol), comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, vive con su esposa y sus tres hijos en casa propia, Ricardo está solicitando un crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas como: semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, etc. así como muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con su trabajo y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: Ricardo is 37 years old. For 5 years, he has worked in agriculture (growing corn and beans). He sells his products in different markets that are close to his house. He lives with his wife and his three children in their own home. Ricardo is asking for a loan to buy agricultural materials such as seeds, fertilizer, pest control, etc. As seen in the photograph, this is to be able to continue with his work and have better income.

loans.use: to buy agricultural materials such as seeds, fertilizer, pest control, etc.

loans.name: Joveta

texts.en:
Joveta landed at a right place for her needed capital when she joined PMPC. She knew this would be her last chance to get back on her feet when she went broke after her first business went bad. 

PMPC came to Joveta's rescue, lending her money when she needed it the most. Now, she availed herself of another loan for the next cropping season. She loaned an amount to buy fertilizers and insecticides for a good and healthy palay (rice). Joveta perseveres and always believes she will reach her goals and be able to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is 44 years old, married and lives at Poblacion, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines. She has 3 children and all of them are in school. Their only means to earn a living is through fishing.  Despite the strong wind and the heavy rain, her husband will still go fishing to earn and survive. She sells the fish in public places or anywhere she can find a customer. 

Because of the family's financial difficulties, Wilma decided to join Paglaum MPC to avail herself of financial assistance, but she was also happy knowing that she will also be able to save part of her income and obtain other benefits offered by the Cooperative. Now she requests 10,000 PHP to purchase additional fishing nets to be able to catch more fish. Her greatest desire is to see her children finish their studies and live a comfortable life ahead.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: Artelieta

texts.en:
Artelieta, 57 years old, is married with seven children. Her husband works as a farmer but earns just enough for hand-to-mouth needs and she was striving hard to earn a living without a stable job. The education of her seven children and the day-to-day consumption was challenging, so she decided to open a store selling basic commodities.  

They were thankful that they joined Paglaum MPC. With very little capital, they were able to start their sari-sari (general store) business. Their daily sales go the extra mile for the family's needs. They were also able to save their extra income. 

They have applied to Paglaum MPC for additional capital to purchase canned goods, candies and soft drinks. They say they were attracted to Paglaum MPC for the savings and insurance services of the cooperative. They want to gradually expand their little store and taste a good life someday.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, candies and soft drinks.

loans.name: Dana

texts.es:
Dana ha tenido que soportar el duro verdugo del desplazamiento a causa de la violencia, ella vivía en San Carlos y se vio en la obligación de trasladarse hasta Puerto Boyacá en busca de una nueva oportunidad de vida para ella y sus hijos lejos de la violencia, la sangre y las balas.

Hoy en día vive en una humilde casa en la cual se gana la vida vendiendo golosinas, comestibles y minutos a celular, una actividad que aprendió de manera empírica con el afán de conseguir el sustento para sus hijos.

Ella solicita un préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de surtido de golosinas y comestibles para abastecer su pequeño kiosco y capitalizar su actividad.

Con este préstamo para ofrecer una mejor variedad de productos y mejorar sus ventas de una manera considerable.

Hoy en día es una mujer fuerte y con gran espíritu emprendedor.
texts.en:
Dana has had to suffer the torment of displacement due to violence. She used to live in San Carlos and she was forced to move to Puerto Boyacá to seek a new chance in life for her and her children far from the violence, blood and bullets. 

Today she lives in a humble house where she earns a living selling candies, edibles and cellular minutes. She learned this activity on her own in order to support her children. She is asking for a loan to invest in buying an inventory of candies and edibles to capitalize her activity.  

With this loan, she will offer a better variety of products and improve her sales considerably. Today she is a strong woman with a great entrepreneurial spirit.

loans.use: to buy an inventory of candies and edibles to stock her little kiosk and capitalize her activity.

loans.name: Domingas

texts.en:
Domingas lives in Viqueque. She has been involved in business activities since 2012. She started with her own working capital of $50. She is a tailor and she also sells donuts. 

So, Domingas is requesting a loan of $800 (USD) from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants to improve her business. She is very interested in her business, so she is taking this loan from Tuba Rai Metin to buy more materials such as sewing thread, sewing needles, scissors, rope yards, sewing fabrics, and other items including donuts. She needs the loan from Tuba Rai Metin because she wants to improve the management of her business and she hopes to open a bigger store in the future.

loans.use: to buy sewing thread, sewing needles, scissors, rope yards, sewing fabrics, and other items including donuts

loans.name: Domingas

texts.en: Domingas is married and she has 1 child. She is a business woman. She has a kiosk and she also sells clothes. She is requesting a loan of $ 1500.00 from Tuba Rai Metin, because  she wants to buy additional items including sugar, coffee, candles, sardines, umbrella, toothpaste, soft drinks, clothes and other things to sell. She has been involved in business activities since 2004 when she started with her own working capital of $500.00. She is happy to be taking a loan from Tuba Rai Metin because with this loan from Tuba Rai Metin, she can know how to improve management of her business. With good management, she can open a big store in the future. So, she is happy with the loan that is offered from Tuba Rai Metin for her.

loans.use: to buy sugar, coffee, candles, sardines, umbrella, toothpaste, soft drinks, clothes and other things to sell

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Kan is 53 years old, a married farmer with four children living in Takeo province of Cambodia. She has been a farmer since 1993. Three of her children are garment-factory workers. Her husband is a wedding-song musician. All of them can earn approximately $21 daily. 

To improve her family finances, Kan would like to request a loan to buy an ox and a cart for her husband and her youngest son to transport sand to sell when he is free from work. This loan will help her husband earn more income. In the future, she is going to build a new house.

loans.use: to buy an ox and a cart for her husband and youngest son to transport sand to sell.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina is earning a living doing farming activities. At the age of 63 and married, she never stopped pursuing her goals for the sake of the family. 

Marcelina is a full fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. She maintains her membership in good standing without records of default. From her desire to earn extra income, she engaged in a sari-sari (small grocery) store business, PMPC stood by her to start her chosen business. 

Now, she applied for a loan to restock her store with basic commodities and other consumable items to increase her inventory and also to purchase bags of farm fertilizer.  Marcelina continues to seek business ideas for farming, proof that she has the determination to fulfill her dreams.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities and purchase bags of farm fertilizer.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: Juan vive en concubinato y tiene un hijo que esta por cumplir un año. Juan vive y trabaja en la región de Palomar, Juan y su familia ocupan la casa del padre de su compañera, una vivienda de ladrillo y cemento bastante rústica. Juan es agricultor y tambien se dedica a engordar torillos para revenderlos, Juan pide un credito para comprar un par de torillos. El cliente recibe ayuda de su compañera que esta a cargo de una tienda de barrio en Palomar, pero el negocio es propiedad del padre de esta mujer, por lo que Juan no recibe mucha colaboración, por eso necesita su ayuda para salir adelante y empezar a ser más independiente. Entre las condiciones duras de trabajo esta la intransitabilidad del terreno cuando llueve y el hecho de que JUan debe caminar mucho desde su casa hasta el lugar donde tiene su sembradío y atiende a sus torillos
texts.en: Juan is in a common law marriage and he has a son who is about to turn a year old. Juan lives and works in the Palomar region. Juan and his family live in his father in law's house. It is a brick and cement house and is very rustic. Juan is a farmer and he also fattens up bull calves to sell. Juan is asking for a loan to buy a pair of bull calves. He gets help from his wife who runs a neighborhood store in Palomar, but the store belongs to her father, so Juan doesn't get a lot of help. That is why he needs your help to get ahead and start to be more independent. His challenges are the tough work conditions and the impassibility of the land when it rains and the fact that Juan has to walk a lot from his house to his crops and where he cares for his bull calves.

loans.use: to buy a pair of bull calves.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina is a businesswoman who lives in Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She vends snacks to help support the needs of her family. 

She is asking for help from PMPC  for the purpose of purchasing banana, "camote" (sweet potato), sugar, baking ingredients which she will sell near the school. She is hoping that she will be able to repay her debt from her profits and will be able to assist with the financial needs of her students.

loans.use: To purchase banana, camote, sugar, baking ingredients.

location.town: Oroquieta-Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Ronila

texts.en:
Ronila is 36 years old and married with six children. Four of her children are in school.

Ronila works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Ronila has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Ronila aspires to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 42 years old and married with four children, two of whom are in school.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Erlinda is borrowing PHP 28,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Erlinda has been raising pigs for ten years and also earns additional income from farming rice.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita works hard to support her family. Carmelita is married and has a fish-vending business in the Philippines.

Carmelita requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

Carmelita has been in this business for 20 years now.

Carmelita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more women and men's clothing wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for the process of obtaining her bachelor's degree in Administration.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is 58 years old and a resident of New Dapitan, Rizal, Philippines. She has children, both them are in college.  She owns a "sari-sari store" (small grocery store) that forms part of their house, and her neighbors are their clients. 

Since, she has a college student to support, she has decided to improve their small business to support their children. So she has requested a loan at Paglaum MPC to purchase more inventory for her sari-sari store. Aside from the financial assistance, she also received add-on benefits like insurance, savings, etc. 

She hopes that with Paglaum's help, she will become a successful businesswoman someday.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es: María tiene 53 años de edad y vive con su hija en casa propia, ella se dedica a la venta de antojitos (yuca, papas fritas, enchiladas, pastelitos de carne, etc.) su negocio está ubicado cerca de su casa y con las ventas que realiza logra salir adelante con los gastos del hogar, ella está solicitando un crédito para comprar más materia prima como: yuca, papas, maíz, verduras, carne, etc. y así continuar con su trabajo para tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
María, 53, lives with her daughter in her own home. She makes a living selling snacks (yucca, potatoes, fries, enchiladas, shepard’s pie, etc.). Her business is near her house. With the sales she makes, she will pay household expenses.

She is requesting this loan to buy more primary materials such as yucca, potatoes, corn, vegetables, meat, and other items so she can keep working and earn more income.

loans.use: to buy yucca, potatoes, corn, vegetables, meat, and other items.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is single and has a fish-vending business in the Philippines.

Elvie requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell to her customers.

Elvie has been in this business for 4 years now.

In the future, Elvie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian works hard to support two children. She is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines.

Vivian requested a PHP 1,800 loan through NWTF in order to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency.

Vivian is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Philemon

texts.en:
Philemon is 29 years of age, a hard worker and always says, “I eat from my sweat.” He is based in Kapsumai, a rural village in Kapsowar. He has one lovely angel-looking boy. Philemon has been practicing farming for the past six years and has never looked back. His primary source of income has been milk, eggs and crops. 

Most of the small holder farmers in Kapsumai village own approximately half an acre per household and this has made them work extra hard to fully utilize their farms. Philemon has been practicing mixed farming and he enjoys the income he gets, but he has been facing challenges delivering his products to the market. Kapsumai village is a very remote area and the roads are in pathetic condition; this has hampered Philemon from making timely delivery of products to the market while still fresh. Philemon sells vegetables, milk and tomatoes which are very perishable and require quick delivery if you are to fetch a high price. Philemon is seeking a loan to buy a motorbike that will help him deliver his products to the market in a timely way so he can overcome the challenge of facing losses. Through the loan he will deliver the products timely to the market and this means he will never suffer losses, which will translate into an immediate increase in profits. Philemon plans to employ someone who will help him on the farm and deliver products to his large client base. Profits from the loan will be used to comfortably repay the loan fully and invest in a solid foundation for his family to come.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to deliver his products to the market

loans.name: Blanca Luz

texts.es:
